abstracts.cdata!:
The project outcome was unsatisfactory,
            though sustainability is likely, with modest institutional
            development impacts. Despite consistency with government
            priorities, and largely with the Country Assistance Strategy
            objectives, major project risks, identified at the design
            stages, but neglected further on, hampered the quality of
            project implementation. Key lessons suggest that: 1) since
            the Bank does not have a high comparative advantage in
            funding technical assistance projects which are not
            competitively prone, nor economically strong, aid agencies,
            and grants available for environmental pilot activities
            would be suited, in particular, for building environmental
            capacity, and in general, for institutional projects. But,
            where institutional development projects for new agencies
            are undertaken by the Bank, the perceived importance of the
            Bank advisory role may thrust the political will, and donor
            coordination, essential for project success; 2) the design
            for environmental management projects, should take into
            account the socioeconomic context of the country, where top
            management should ensure that environmental goals are met at
            the highest level; and, 3) since legislation prepared under
            projects is rarely enacted during the life of the project,
            the Bank should find ways to continue support for adoption
            of such legislation, to reach the final targets on which the
            impact of the project depends.
